_link.title: I can compare energy content of different food groups

toLevel2.question: Which macronutrient provides the most energy per gram?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Fats provide 37 kJ g⁻¹, which is more than twice the energy per gram compared to proteins (17 kJ g⁻¹) or carbohydrates (16 kJ g⁻¹).

distractors.explanation: Proteins provide 17 kJ g⁻¹, which is less than half the energy per gram of fats (37 kJ g⁻¹).
Carbohydrates provide 16 kJ g⁻¹, which is less than half the energy per gram of fats (37 kJ g⁻¹).
Water provides no energy (0 kJ g⁻¹) as it contains no combustible chemical bonds.

toLevel2.question: What is the reference energy value for carbohydrates?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The reference energy value for carbohydrates is 16 kJ g⁻¹, which is the lowest of the three macronutrients.

distractors.explanation: 37 kJ g⁻¹ is the reference value for fats, not carbohydrates.
17 kJ g⁻¹ is the reference value for proteins, not carbohydrates.
26 kJ g⁻¹ is not a standard reference value for any macronutrient. Carbohydrates are 16 kJ g⁻¹.

toLevel2.question: How much energy does 10 g of fat provide?

distractors.explanation: 170 kJ is the energy from 10 g of protein (10 × 17), not fat.
160 kJ is the energy from 10 g of carbohydrate (10 × 16), not fat.
37 kJ is the energy from only 1 g of fat. For 10 g, multiply by 10 to get 370 kJ.

toLevel2.question: Which macronutrient has the lowest energy content per gram?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Carbohydrates provide 16 kJ g⁻¹, which is slightly less than proteins (17 kJ g⁻¹) and much less than fats (37 kJ g⁻¹).

distractors.explanation: Fats have the highest energy per gram at 37 kJ g⁻¹, not the lowest.
Proteins provide 17 kJ g⁻¹, which is slightly higher than carbohydrates (16 kJ g⁻¹).
The three macronutrients have different energy values: fats 37, proteins 17, carbohydrates 16 kJ g⁻¹.

toLevel2.question: What is the reference energy value for proteins?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The reference energy value for proteins is 17 kJ g⁻¹, which is between carbohydrates (16 kJ g⁻¹) and fats (37 kJ g⁻¹).

distractors.explanation: 37 kJ g⁻¹ is the reference value for fats, not proteins.
16 kJ g⁻¹ is the reference value for carbohydrates, not proteins.
27 kJ g⁻¹ is not a standard reference value. The correct value for proteins is 17 kJ g⁻¹.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about macronutrient energy values.
toLevel2.sentence: Fats provide {{blank:1}} kJ g⁻¹, making them the most energy-dense macronutrient.

1.correctExplanation: The reference energy value for fats is 37 kJ g⁻¹, more than double that of proteins or carbohydrates.

distractors.explanation: 17 kJ g⁻¹ is the reference value for proteins, not fats.
16 kJ g⁻¹ is the reference value for carbohydrates, not fats.
27 kJ g⁻¹ is not a standard reference value for any macronutrient.

toLevel2.sentence: Fats provide more than {{blank:1}} the energy per gram compared to carbohydrates or proteins.

1.correctExplanation: Fats (37 kJ g⁻¹) provide more than twice the energy of carbohydrates (16 kJ g⁻¹) and proteins (17 kJ g⁻¹).

distractors.explanation: Fats provide more energy, not less. They have more than twice, not half, the energy of carbohydrates.
37 ÷ 16 = 2.31 and 37 ÷ 17 = 2.18, which is just over twice, not three times.
Fats have significantly more energy per gram than carbohydrates or proteins, not equal amounts.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about energy-dense foods.
toLevel2.sentence: High-fat foods have higher energy content because {{blank:1}} provide the most energy per gram of all macronutrients.

1.correctExplanation: Fats at 37 kJ g⁻¹ are the most energy-dense macronutrient, so foods rich in fat have higher total energy content.

distractors.explanation: Proteins provide 17 kJ g⁻¹, which is less than half the energy of fats (37 kJ g⁻¹).
Carbohydrates provide 16 kJ g⁻¹, less than half the energy of fats (37 kJ g⁻¹).
Vitamins do not provide significant energy to the body. Fats are the most energy-dense macronutrient.

toLevel2.question: Proteins and carbohydrates have very similar energy content per gram.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Proteins provide 17 kJ g⁻¹ and carbohydrates provide 16 kJ g⁻¹, a difference of only 1 kJ g⁻¹, making them very similar.

distractors.explanation: This statement is true. Proteins (17 kJ g⁻¹) and carbohydrates (16 kJ g⁻¹) differ by only 1 kJ g⁻¹.

toLevel2.question: Carbohydrates provide more energy per gram than fats.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Fats provide 37 kJ g⁻¹, which is much more than carbohydrates at 16 kJ g⁻¹. Fats are the most energy-dense macronutrient.

distractors.explanation: Carbohydrates (16 kJ g⁻¹) provide less than half the energy per gram of fats (37 kJ g⁻¹).

toLevel3.question: Why are fats described as the most efficient energy storage molecules in organisms?
toLevel3.correct: Fats store more than twice the energy per gram compared to other macronutrients
toLevel3.correctExplanation: At 37 kJ g⁻¹, fats store over twice the energy per gram of proteins (17 kJ g⁻¹) or carbohydrates (16 kJ g⁻¹), making them the most mass-efficient way to store energy.

distractors.answer: Fats are the easiest macronutrient to digest
distractors.explanation: Digestibility does not determine energy storage efficiency. Fats are efficient because of their high energy density.

distractors.answer: Fats contain more water than other macronutrients
distractors.explanation: Fats actually contain less water than glycogen stores. Their efficiency comes from high energy per gram.

distractors.answer: Fats are found in all foods
distractors.explanation: Being common does not make fats efficient for energy storage. Their high energy density (37 kJ g⁻¹) is what matters.

toLevel3.question: A food contains 20 g of protein and 20 g of carbohydrate. Which macronutrient contributes more energy?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Protein: 20 × 17 = 340 kJ. Carbohydrate: 20 × 16 = 320 kJ. Protein contributes 20 kJ more due to its slightly higher energy value per gram.

distractors.explanation: Carbohydrate provides 320 kJ while protein provides 340 kJ. Protein has a slightly higher reference value (17 vs 16 kJ g⁻¹).

distractors.answer: Both contribute exactly the same energy
distractors.explanation: They are similar but not identical: protein gives 340 kJ and carbohydrate gives 320 kJ.
Fat is not mentioned in this food. Only protein and carbohydrate are being compared.

toLevel3.question: Why does a tablespoon of oil (about 14 g) contain more energy than a tablespoon of sugar (about 12 g)?
toLevel3.correct: Oil is fat (37 kJ g⁻¹) while sugar is carbohydrate (16 kJ g⁻¹)
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Oil: 14 × 37 = 518 kJ. Sugar: 12 × 16 = 192 kJ. The much higher energy density of fat explains why oil has more energy despite similar serving sizes.

distractors.answer: Oil weighs more than sugar per tablespoon
distractors.explanation: While the masses differ slightly, the main reason is the much higher energy value per gram of fat (37 vs 16 kJ g⁻¹).
Sugar does contain energy (16 kJ g⁻¹ as a carbohydrate), but it is much less energy-dense than fat.

distractors.answer: Oil is a liquid so it has more energy
distractors.explanation: The physical state does not determine energy content. Fat's higher energy per gram (37 vs 16 kJ g⁻¹) is the reason.

toLevel3.question: By what factor is the energy content of fat greater than that of carbohydrate per gram?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Fat ÷ carbohydrate = 37 ÷ 16 = 2.31. Fats provide about 2.3 times the energy per gram compared to carbohydrates.

distractors.explanation: 1.5 × 16 = 24, which is much less than 37 kJ g⁻¹. The correct factor is 37 ÷ 16 = 2.31.
3.0 × 16 = 48, which is more than 37 kJ g⁻¹. The correct factor is 37 ÷ 16 = 2.31.
A factor of 1.0 would mean equal energy per gram, but fat (37 kJ g⁻¹) has much more than carbohydrate (16 kJ g⁻¹).

toLevel3.question: A nutritionist wants to explain why nuts are energy-dense. Which macronutrient composition best explains their high energy content?
toLevel3.correct: Nuts are high in fat, which has the highest energy per gram
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Nuts typically contain a large proportion of fat (37 kJ g⁻¹), making them energy-dense. Their high fat content is the main contributor to their high kilojoule count.

distractors.explanation: Most nuts are relatively low in carbohydrate. Their energy density comes primarily from their high fat content.

distractors.answer: Nuts contain a lot of water
distractors.explanation: Water provides no energy. Nuts are actually relatively dry, and their energy comes from fat content.
Fibre is indigestible and provides no metabolizable energy. The high fat content of nuts explains their energy density.

toLevel3.question: A student calculates that 50 g of fat provides 1850 kJ and 50 g of carbohydrate provides 800 kJ. What is the energy difference?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Difference = 1850 − 800 = 1050 kJ. This large difference demonstrates how much more energy-dense fats are compared to carbohydrates.

distractors.explanation: 2650 kJ is the sum of both values, not the difference.
This halves the correct difference. The actual difference is 1850 − 800 = 1050 kJ.
This may result from calculating the difference per gram (37 − 16 = 21) and multiplying by 10. The correct difference is 1050 kJ.

toLevel3.sentence: Fats provide about {{blank:1}} times more energy per gram than proteins, based on reference values of 37 and 17 kJ g⁻¹.

1.correctExplanation: 37 ÷ 17 = 2.18 ≈ 2.2. Fats provide about 2.2 times the energy per gram compared to proteins.

distractors.explanation: 37 ÷ 17 = 2.18, not 1.1. Fats provide more than double, not just 10% more energy.
This may come from dividing 37 by 10. The correct ratio is 37 ÷ 17 = 2.18.
A ratio of 0.5 would mean fats have half the energy of protein, which is the reverse of reality.

toLevel3.sentence: A food with 15 g of fat provides 15 × 37 = {{blank:1}} kJ from fat alone.

1.correctExplanation: 15 × 37 = 555 kJ. Each gram of fat provides 37 kJ of energy.

distractors.explanation: 15 × 17 = 255 kJ is the energy from 15 g of protein, not fat.
15 × 16 = 240 kJ is the energy from 15 g of carbohydrate, not fat.
10 × 37 = 370 kJ would be the energy from 10 g of fat, not 15 g.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the statement about food labelling.
toLevel3.sentence: High-fat foods have higher kilojoule counts on nutrition labels because fat has an energy density of {{blank:1}} kJ g⁻¹, which is the highest of all macronutrients.

1.correctExplanation: Fat has the highest energy density at 37 kJ g⁻¹, explaining why fatty foods have the highest kilojoule values on labels.

distractors.explanation: 17 kJ g⁻¹ is the energy density of proteins, not fats.
16 kJ g⁻¹ is the energy density of carbohydrates, not fats.
27 kJ g⁻¹ is not the standard reference value for any macronutrient.

toLevel3.question: Replacing 10 g of carbohydrate with 10 g of fat in a food would increase its energy content by 210 kJ.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Removing 10 g carbohydrate loses 10 × 16 = 160 kJ. Adding 10 g fat gains 10 × 37 = 370 kJ. Net change = 370 − 160 = 210 kJ increase.

distractors.explanation: This is true. The net increase is 370 − 160 = 210 kJ because fat provides 37 kJ g⁻¹ while carbohydrate provides only 16 kJ g⁻¹.

toLevel4.question: Food A contains 30 g fat, 20 g protein, and 50 g carbohydrate per 100 g. Food B contains 5 g fat, 25 g protein, and 60 g carbohydrate per 100 g. Which food has higher energy per 100 g?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Food A: (30 × 37) + (20 × 17) + (50 × 16) = 1110 + 340 + 800 = 2250 kJ. Food B: (5 × 37) + (25 × 17) + (60 × 16) = 185 + 425 + 960 = 1570 kJ. Food A has higher energy due to its higher fat content.

distractors.explanation: Food B provides 1570 kJ per 100 g, less than Food A's 2250 kJ. Food A has much more fat, which has the highest energy per gram.
Food A (2250 kJ) has considerably more energy than Food B (1570 kJ) due to its higher fat content.
It can be calculated: Food A = 2250 kJ and Food B = 1570 kJ per 100 g.

toLevel4.question: A student wants to reduce the energy content of a recipe by 370 kJ. They can either remove fat or carbohydrate. What mass of each would need to be removed?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Fat: 370 ÷ 37 = 10.0 g. Carbohydrate: 370 ÷ 16 = 23.1 g. Less fat needs to be removed because fat has higher energy density.

distractors.explanation: 10 g carbohydrate only provides 160 kJ, not 370 kJ. More carbohydrate (23.1 g) must be removed to match 370 kJ.
This reverses the values. Fat has higher energy density, so less fat (10 g) needs to be removed.
These are the reference energy values in kJ g⁻¹, not the masses needed. Divide 370 by each value to get the mass.

toLevel4.question: A 200 g meal provides 3200 kJ. If 40% of the energy comes from fat, how many grams of fat are in the meal?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Energy from fat = 0.40 × 3200 = 1280 kJ. Mass of fat = 1280 ÷ 37 = 34.6 g.

distractors.explanation: This calculates 40% of the total mass (200 g), not 40% of the energy. The mass of fat must be found from the energy value.
This divides 1280 by 100 instead of by 37. Mass = energy ÷ energy density = 1280 ÷ 37 = 34.6 g.
This divides the total energy (3200) by 37, ignoring that only 40% comes from fat.

toLevel4.question: Two snack bars have the same total mass of 50 g. Bar X contains 20 g fat and 30 g carbohydrate. Bar Y contains 10 g fat and 40 g carbohydrate. What is the energy difference between them?

distractors.explanation: This calculates the energy from 10 g fat (10 × 37), but does not account for the 10 g of carbohydrate replacing it.
This calculates the energy from 10 g carbohydrate. The difference accounts for both the extra fat and the reduced carbohydrate.
This sums both bars' energies (1220 + 1010). The question asks for the difference, not the sum.

toLevel4.question: A food has 15 g protein, 8 g fat, and 35 g carbohydrate per serving. What percentage of the total energy comes from fat?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Protein: 15 × 17 = 255 kJ. Fat: 8 × 37 = 296 kJ. Carbohydrate: 35 × 16 = 560 kJ. Total = 1111 kJ. Fat percentage = (296 ÷ 1111) × 100 = 26.6%.

distractors.explanation: This calculates fat as a percentage of total mass (8 ÷ 58 × 100), not as a percentage of total energy.
37 kJ g⁻¹ is the energy density of fat, not the percentage of total energy from fat in this food.
This does not match the correct calculation based on the given macronutrient amounts.

toLevel4.question: An athlete needs to consume 10 000 kJ per day. If they want 60% of their energy from carbohydrate, how many grams of carbohydrate do they need?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Energy from carbohydrate = 0.60 × 10 000 = 6000 kJ. Mass = 6000 ÷ 16 = 375 g of carbohydrate.

distractors.explanation: This calculates 60% of 1000 g, which has no basis. The correct approach uses energy: 6000 ÷ 16 = 375 g.
This divides 6000 by 37 (fat reference value) instead of 16 (carbohydrate reference value).
This divides 6000 by 17 (protein reference value) instead of 16 (carbohydrate reference value).

toLevel4.question: A student compares olive oil (100% fat) with white rice (approximately 80% carbohydrate, 7% protein, 1% fat by mass). Per gram, approximately how many times more energy does olive oil provide?

distractors.explanation: Olive oil has much more energy per gram (37 kJ) than rice (~14.4 kJ), so the ratio is about 2.6, not 1.0.
37 ÷ 14.4 = 2.58, which is about 2.6 times, not 5.0 times.
This would mean rice has only 1 kJ g⁻¹, which is far too low. Rice provides about 14.4 kJ g⁻¹.

toLevel4.sentence: A food with 25 g of fat provides 25 × 37 = {{blank:1}} kJ, while 25 g of carbohydrate provides only 25 × 16 = 400 kJ.

1.correctExplanation: 25 × 37 = 925 kJ from fat. This is 525 kJ more than the 400 kJ from the same mass of carbohydrate.

distractors.explanation: 400 kJ is the energy from 25 g of carbohydrate (25 × 16), not 25 g of fat.
25 × 17 = 425 kJ is the energy from 25 g of protein, not fat.
10 × 37 = 370 kJ is the energy from 10 g of fat. For 25 g, multiply: 25 × 37 = 925 kJ.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the energy calculation for a mixed food.
toLevel4.sentence: A food containing 10 g fat, 10 g protein, and 10 g carbohydrate has a total energy of (10 × 37) + (10 × 17) + (10 × 16) = {{blank:1}} kJ.

1.correctExplanation: 370 + 170 + 160 = 700 kJ. Fat contributes the most (370 kJ) despite all three macronutrients being present in equal mass.

distractors.explanation: This may add the reference values (37 + 17 + 16 = 70) and multiply by 3, giving 210. The correct sum is 370 + 170 + 160 = 700 kJ.
This does not match any correct calculation. Each macronutrient contributes 10 g × its reference value.
This may result from using 30 g for one component. With 10 g each: 370 + 170 + 160 = 700 kJ.

toLevel4.sentence: In a food with 700 kJ total energy where fat contributes 370 kJ, the percentage of energy from fat is (370 ÷ 700) × 100 = {{blank:1}}%.

1.correctExplanation: (370 ÷ 700) × 100 = 52.9%. Fat contributes more than half the total energy even though it makes up only one-third of the total macronutrient mass.

distractors.explanation: 33.3% is fat's contribution by mass (10 g out of 30 g), not by energy. Fat's energy percentage is higher due to its greater energy density.
37 is the energy density of fat in kJ g⁻¹, not the percentage of total energy from fat.
This does not match the calculation (370 ÷ 700) × 100 = 52.9%.

toLevel5.question: A food manufacturer reformulates a product by replacing 5 g of fat with 5 g of carbohydrate. By how much does the energy content change per serving?
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Removing 5 g fat loses 5 × 37 = 185 kJ. Adding 5 g carbohydrate gains 5 × 16 = 80 kJ. Net change = 80 − 185 = −105 kJ (decrease).

distractors.explanation: The energy decreases, not increases, because fat (37 kJ g⁻¹) is being replaced by the less energy-dense carbohydrate (16 kJ g⁻¹).
21 kJ g⁻¹ is the difference in energy density per gram, but the change applies to 5 g: 5 × 21 = 105 kJ decrease.
Replacing fat with carbohydrate changes the energy content because they have different energy densities (37 vs 16 kJ g⁻¹).

toLevel5.question: Two meals have the same total energy of 3000 kJ. Meal A gets 50% of its energy from fat. Meal B gets 20% from fat. How many more grams of fat does Meal A contain compared to Meal B?

distractors.explanation: This represents 30% of the total energy difference but does not correctly convert energy to mass using the fat reference value.
900 is the difference in energy from fat in kJ (1500 − 600), not in grams. Divide by 37 to get the mass.
40.5 g is the total fat in Meal A, not the difference between the two meals.

toLevel5.question: A student analyses a food label: per 100 g, the food provides 1800 kJ with 20 g fat, 15 g protein, and 45 g carbohydrate. Do these macronutrients account for all the listed energy?
toLevel5.correct: No, the macronutrients account for only 1715 kJ
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Fat: 20 × 37 = 740 kJ. Protein: 15 × 17 = 255 kJ. Carbohydrate: 45 × 16 = 720 kJ. Total = 1715 kJ. The remaining 85 kJ may come from other sources such as alcohol or rounding.

distractors.answer: Yes, they account for exactly 1800 kJ
distractors.explanation: The calculated total is 1715 kJ, which is 85 kJ less than the listed 1800 kJ.

distractors.answer: No, the macronutrients account for 2000 kJ
distractors.explanation: The correct total is 740 + 255 + 720 = 1715 kJ, not 2000 kJ.

distractors.answer: No, the macronutrients account for 1200 kJ
distractors.explanation: 1200 kJ is too low. The correct calculation is 740 + 255 + 720 = 1715 kJ.

toLevel5.question: A dietitian recommends reducing fat intake from 35% to 25% of total daily energy for a person consuming 8000 kJ per day. How much less fat (in grams) should they eat?

distractors.explanation: 800 is the difference in energy from fat in kJ, not in grams. Divide 800 by 37 to get 21.6 g.
This is the 10% difference in percentage points, not the actual mass reduction in grams.
75.7 g is the original fat intake, not the reduction. The reduction is 75.7 − 54.1 = 21.6 g.

toLevel5.question: A student claims: 'Since fat has about twice the energy of protein per gram, a food with 10 g fat always has more energy than a food with 20 g protein.' Evaluate this claim.
toLevel5.correct: The claim is correct; 10 g fat (370 kJ) exceeds 20 g protein (340 kJ)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: 10 g fat = 10 × 37 = 370 kJ. 20 g protein = 20 × 17 = 340 kJ. Since 370 > 340, the claim is correct — even twice the mass of protein provides less energy than fat.

distractors.answer: The claim is incorrect; 20 g protein has more energy
distractors.explanation: 20 g protein = 340 kJ, which is less than 10 g fat = 370 kJ. The claim is correct.

distractors.answer: The claim is incorrect; both are equal
distractors.explanation: 370 kJ from fat and 340 kJ from protein are not equal. The claim is correct.

distractors.answer: The claim cannot be evaluated without more information
distractors.explanation: It can be evaluated using reference values: 10 × 37 = 370 kJ vs 20 × 17 = 340 kJ.

toLevel5.question: An endurance athlete replaces 30 g of carbohydrate with 30 g of fat in their pre-race meal. How does this affect the total energy and the mass of the meal?
toLevel5.correct: Energy increases by 630 kJ with no change in meal mass
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Energy change: (30 × 37) − (30 × 16) = 1110 − 480 = +630 kJ. The total mass remains the same (30 g replaced by 30 g), but energy increases significantly.

distractors.answer: Energy decreases by 630 kJ with no change in mass
distractors.explanation: Replacing carbohydrate (16 kJ g⁻¹) with fat (37 kJ g⁻¹) increases energy, not decreases it.

distractors.answer: Energy increases by 630 kJ and mass increases by 30 g
distractors.explanation: The mass does not change because 30 g of carbohydrate is replaced by 30 g of fat.

distractors.answer: Energy and mass both remain unchanged
distractors.explanation: While mass stays the same, energy increases by 630 kJ because fat has higher energy density.

toLevel5.question: A food scientist compares two formulations of a protein bar (each 60 g). Formulation X: 10 g fat, 25 g protein, 20 g carbohydrate. Formulation Y: 5 g fat, 30 g protein, 20 g carbohydrate. Which has more energy and by how much?

distractors.explanation: Formulation X has more energy (1115 vs 1015 kJ) because replacing protein with fat increases energy per gram.
X has 1115 kJ and Y has 1015 kJ; they are not equal. The extra fat in X more than compensates for less protein.
185 kJ is the energy from 5 g fat alone (5 × 37). The actual difference accounts for both the fat and protein changes.

toLevel5.question: Why do nutrition labels express the proportion of energy from fat as a percentage of total energy rather than as a percentage of total mass?
toLevel5.correct: Fat's high energy density means its energy contribution is disproportionate to its mass contribution
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Because fat has 37 kJ g⁻¹ compared to 16–17 kJ g⁻¹ for other macronutrients, a small mass of fat contributes a disproportionately large share of total energy. Mass percentage would underrepresent fat's energy contribution.

distractors.answer: Mass percentages are harder to calculate
distractors.explanation: Mass percentages are actually simpler to calculate. The reason for energy percentages is that mass would underrepresent fat's energy contribution.

distractors.answer: Energy percentages make products look healthier
distractors.explanation: Energy percentages are used for accuracy, not marketing. They better reflect the actual energy contribution of each macronutrient.

distractors.answer: All macronutrients have the same mass-to-energy ratio
distractors.explanation: Macronutrients have very different mass-to-energy ratios (37, 17, 16 kJ g⁻¹), which is exactly why energy percentages are more informative.

toLevel5.prompt: Analyse the effect of a dietary substitution.
toLevel5.sentence: Replacing 20 g of carbohydrate with 20 g of protein changes the energy by (20 × 17) − (20 × 16) = {{blank:1}} kJ.

1.correctExplanation: Protein energy: 20 × 17 = 340 kJ. Carbohydrate energy: 20 × 16 = 320 kJ. Change = 340 − 320 = +20 kJ.

distractors.explanation: The energies are not equal. Protein (17 kJ g⁻¹) provides slightly more than carbohydrate (16 kJ g⁻¹), giving a +20 kJ change.
This adds the reference values (17 + 16 = 33) and multiplies by something incorrectly. The change is 340 − 320 = 20 kJ.
This sums both energy values (340 + 320). The question asks for the difference: 340 − 320 = 20 kJ.

toLevel5.sentence: To get the same 370 kJ from carbohydrate as from 10 g of fat, you would need 370 ÷ 16 = {{blank:1}} g of carbohydrate.

1.correctExplanation: 370 ÷ 16 = 23.1 g. More than twice the mass of carbohydrate is needed to match the energy from 10 g of fat.

distractors.explanation: 10 g of carbohydrate provides only 160 kJ, not 370 kJ. More carbohydrate is needed: 370 ÷ 16 = 23.1 g.
This divides 370 by 10 instead of by 16. The correct calculation is 370 ÷ 16 = 23.1 g.
16 is the reference value for carbohydrate (kJ g⁻¹), not the mass needed. Mass = 370 ÷ 16 = 23.1 g.
